functions.name: delegate
functions.desc:
Ask a capable helper for help looking up a piece of information or performing an action.
Do not simply repeat what the user said as instructions.
You should use this to break up complex user queries into multiple simpler steps.
NOTE: Helpers cannot see previous parts of your conversation.

instructions.description: Detailed instructions on what your helper should do to help you.

msg.content: In what year was each member of Blackpink born?
In what year was each member of Blackpink born?

function.name: delegate
function.arguments: {"instructions":"Find out the birth years of each member of the K-pop group Blackpink."}

functions.name: search
functions.desc: Search Wikipedia for an article with the given title, and get its content. If no such article is found, return similar article names.

msg.content: Find out the birth years of each member of the K-pop group Blackpink.

No page with that title exists. Try searching for one of these similar articles instead:
- Blackpink
- Lisa (rapper)
- Jisoo
- Shut Down (Blackpink song)
- Rosé (singer)
- The Girls (Blackpink song)
- Blackpink: Light Up the Sky
- Jennie (singer)
- Blackpink House
- List of songs recorded by Blackpink

msg.name: search

msg.content:
<document>
<title>Blackpink</title>
<fragment>
For members who had left their lives outside of South Korea, the pace of training alongside the culture shock was especially difficult.[2] Preparations for Blackpink's debut began as early as 2011, when YG Entertainment revealed on November 14 that their new girl group would debut in the early half of 2012 and feature at least seven members.[3] Since then, numerous news and rumors surfaced surrounding the new girl group's debut being delayed, although there had been no official information.[4][5] It was only on May 18, 2016, that YG Entertainment confirmed the girl group would debut that July, stating that the members were selected through years of stiff competition.[6] The label later confirmed that Jang Hanna and Moon Sua, who were introduced to the public as potential members of the new girl group, were not included in the lineup.[7][8]


</fragment>
<fragment>
18. **^** Kim, Yuyoung (August 9, 2016). "YG Entertainment unveils K-pop group BlackPink". Archived from the original on October 2, 2023. Retrieved October 2, 2023 – via Naver.
19. **^** "[블랙핑크 VS 투애니원③] 블랙핑크는 누구?". *Donga News*. August 12, 2016. Archived from the original on June 12, 2018. Retrieved June 4, 2019.
20. **^** "YG reveals teasers for new girl group member Jisoo". *Asia Today*. Archived from the original on June 16, 2016. Retrieved October 2, 2023.
21. **^** Moon, Wan-sik (June 17, 2021). "블랙핑크 지수 공개 5주년 전 세계 팬들 축하 'Five Years with Jisoo'" [Blackpink Jisoo's 5th Anniversary Celebration of Fans Around the World 'Five Years with Jisoo'] (in Korean). Archived from the original on October 2, 2023. Retrieved October 2, 2023 – via Naver.

</fragment>
<fragment>

162. **^** "Bad Bunny's *Un Verano Sin Ti* announced as winner of IFPI's Global Album Award". *International Federation of the Phonographic Industry*. February 24, 2023. Archived from the original on February 24, 2023. Retrieved February 24, 2023.

165. **^**

187. ^ ***a*** ***b*** ***c*** ***d*** Hwang Mi-hyun; Ahn Tae-hyun (December 31, 2022). "빌보드 정상 찍고 글로벌 '셀럽' 등극한 블랙핑크 [2022 결산]" [BLACKPINK, which reached the top of the Billboard charts and became a global 'celebrity' [2022 settlement]]. *News1* (in Korean). Archived from the original on December 31, 2022. Retrieved December 31, 2022 – via Naver.

74. **^** "Blackpink to Hold Group's First Ever Concert in Seoul... Fan Club BLINK Will Gather for the First Time". *YG Life*. September 12, 2018. Archived from the original on November 9, 2020. Retrieved September 16, 2018.
75. **^** Moon, Kat (June 26, 2020). "Blackpink on the Message of New Single 'How You Like That'". *Time*. Archived from the original on September 28, 2020. Retrieved July 11, 2020.
76. **^** Brooks, Hayden (September 4, 2018). "Dua Lipa Announces Blackink Collab 'Kiss And Make Up': Get The Details". iHeartMedia. Archived from the original on March 29, 2019. Retrieved October 30, 2018.
77. **^** Ainsley, Helen (October 26, 2018). "Blackpink are officially the first ever female K-pop group to enter the Official UK Top 40". Official Charts Company. Archived from the original on October 28, 2018. Retrieved December 27, 2018.

<fragment>
168. **^** Brandle, Lars (February 1, 2023). "BlackPink Sets 'Born Pink' Australia Tour". *Billboard*. Archived from the original on February 1, 2023. Retrieved February 1, 2023.
169. **^** Paul, Larisha; Mier, Tomás (January 10, 2023). "Bad Bunny and Blackpink Make History as 2023 Coachella Headliners, Frank Ocean Makes Grand Return". *Rolling Stone*. Archived from the original on January 10, 2023. Retrieved January 10, 2023.
170. **^** Krol, Charlotte (October 21, 2022). "BLACKPINK to headline BST Hyde Park London in 2023". *NME*. Archived from the original on October 21, 2022. Retrieved October 21, 2022.
171. **^** Muhammad, Latifah (August 14, 2023). "BLACKPINK's Born Pink 'Encore' Tour: Where to Buy Tickets Online for Cheap". *Billboard*. Archived from the original on August 26, 2023. Retrieved August 14, 2023.
172. **^** Ziwei, Puah (May 19, 2023). "Hear a preview of BLACKPINK's new song 'The Girls'". *NME*. Archived from the original on May 22, 2023. Retrieved May 22, 2023.

</fragment>
<fragment>
![](image)The official logo of Blackpink
On June 29, YG Entertainment confirmed that the new girl group would have four members instead of the originally planned nine and revealed its official name as Blackpink.[23] According to a label representative, the group's name meant "pretty isn't everything" and symbolized that "they are a team that encompasses not only beauty, but also great talent".[24] Jisoo later disclosed in a press conference that other group names under consideration included Pink Punk, Baby Monster, and Magnum.[25] Blackpink released their first dance practice video on July 6, which garnered much public attention.[26] On July 29, YG Entertainment confirmed that Blackpink's debut would be on August 8, 2016.[27]



### 2016–2017: Debut, rising popularity, and commercial success[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>

Blackpink have broken numerous records throughout their career; their Born Pink World Tour (2022–23) became the highest grossing concert tour by a female group. They have the most-subscribed and most-viewed music artist channel on YouTube, and are the most-followed and most-streamed girl group on Spotify. Their other accolades include several Guinness World Records, Golden Disc Awards, *Billboard* Music Awards, People’s Choice Awards, and MTV Video Music Awards, among them the first Group of the Year win by a girl group in the 21st century. Blackpink was also the first female Korean group to receive a Brit Award nomination and the first girl group to enter *Forbes*' 30 Under 30 Asia, and was named *Time*'s 2022 Entertainer of the Year. The group has been acknowledged as one of the most powerful celebrities in South Korea by *Forbes* Korea (ranking within the top three in 2019–23), and by former South Korean President Moon Jae-in as a global K-pop phenomenon helping spread K-pop worldwide.




</fragment>
<fragment>
37. **^** Noh, Han-sol (October 31, 2016). "블랙핑크(BLACKPINK), 1일 0시 신곡 '불장난'-'STAY' 공개… '기대 UP'" [Blackpink releases new song 'Playing with Fire' - 'Stay' at midnight on the 1st... ‘Expectations UP’] (in Korean). Archived from the original on October 2, 2023. Retrieved October 2, 2023 – via Top Star News.
38. **^** "[단독] 블랙핑크, 1월6일 '인기가요'+10일 '엠카' 연속 컴백 확정". October 29, 2016. Archived from the original on October 16, 2020. Retrieved November 6, 2016.
39. **^** Benjamin, Jeff (November 11, 2016). "Blackpink Earn Second No. 1 on World Digital Songs, Debut on Social 50". *Billboard*. Archived from the original on November 8, 2020. Retrieved November 11, 2016.
40. ^ ***a*** ***b*** Chan, Anna (August 16, 2023). "Blackpink's History-Making Accomplishments: A Timeline". *Billboard*. Archived from the original on September 20, 2023. Retrieved October 1, 2023.

</fragment>
<fragment>
195. **^** Melas, Chloe (October 1, 2020). "Blackpink discuss working with their music idols Cardi B and Selena Gomez". *CNN*. Archived from the original on October 10, 2022. Retrieved May 31, 2022.
196. **^** Min-sik, Yoon (June 22, 2017). "Black Pink wants to embody both pink and black". *The Korea Herald*. Archived from the original on November 15, 2020. Retrieved May 31, 2022.
197. **^** Thomas, Mona (October 21, 2020). "Blackpink Reveals The Real Meaning Behind Their Group Name". *E! Online*. Archived from the original on November 1, 2020. Retrieved May 31, 2022.
198. **^** Haasch, Palmer (October 8, 2020). "Every Blackpink song, ranked". *Insider*. Archived from the original on November 14, 2020. Retrieved May 31, 2022.
199. **^** Kelley, Caitlin (December 27, 2018). "How 'Girl Crush' Hooked Female Fans and Grappled With Feminism as K-pop Went Global in 2018". *Billboard*. Archived from the original on April 26, 2022. Retrieved May 31, 2022.

</fragment>
<fragment>
Promotions for the group's debut began in the first week of August 2016 with the release of teaser images, videos, and advertisements.[28][29] The first girl group to debut under YG Entertainment in seven years,[30] Blackpink released their debut single album, *Square One*, on August 8, 2016, consisting of tracks "Boombayah" and "Whistle".[30] They charted at number one and two, respectively, on the *Billboard* World Digital Song Sales chart, making Blackpink the fastest act to achieve such a feat and the third YG Entertainment artist to hold the top two positions simultaneously, after Psy and Big Bang.[31] Upon release, "Whistle" quickly swept all the Korean music charts and debuted at number one on the Gaon Digital Chart.[32][33] Blackpink's first music show performance aired on August 14, 2016, on SBS's *Inkigayo*.[34] They won first place on *Inkigayo* fourteen days after their debut.[35] They wrapped up promotions for *Square One* on September 11, 2016, with another win on *Inkigayo*.[36]


</fragment>
<fragment>
173. **^** Zoe, Guy (August 25, 2023). "Blackpink: The Game: the Song Is Streaming Now". *Vulture*. Archived from the original on August 25, 2023. Retrieved August 26, 2023.
174. **^** "Album Chart – Week 34 of 2023". *Circle Chart*. Archived from the original on October 13, 2023. Retrieved October 12, 2023.
175. **^** Elsa, Evangeline (September 13, 2023). "Blackpink becomes the first girl group in 24 years to win 'Best Group' at the VMAs". *Gulf News*. Archived from the original on October 2, 2023. Retrieved October 1, 2023.
176. **^** Yeo, Gladys (August 16, 2023). "BLACKPINK announce 'Born Pink' world tour finale with two shows in Seoul". *NME*. Archived from the original on August 16, 2023. Retrieved August 18, 2023.
177. **^** Sng, Suzanne (April 27, 2023). "Blackpink's Born Pink breaks Spice Girls' record to become highest grossing tour by a female group". *Straits Times*. Archived from the original on September 12, 2023. Retrieved August 18, 2023.

</fragment>
<fragment>

On January 6, 2018, Blackpink released the first episode of their first reality show, *Blackpink House*, which comprised 12 episodes released throughout 2018 following the four members spending 100 days of vacation as they moved into their new dorm, via their official V Live and YouTube channels.[59] On March 28, Blackpink re-released their debut Japanese EP under the name *Re:Blackpink*. The digital version included the same songs as the original release, while the physical version included a DVD of all their music videos and six songs in the Korean language.[60]




</fragment>
<fragment>
190. **^** Kang, Haeryun (May 23, 2022). "How Blackpink Went From Strangers to Sisters to Pop Supernovas". *Rolling Stone*. Archived from the original on May 23, 2022. Retrieved May 23, 2022.
191. **^** "Black Pink talk about 2NE1's influence & their hopes for the future in new interview". *SBS PopAsia*. November 9, 2016. Archived from the original on October 8, 2022. Retrieved May 31, 2022.
192. **^** Weisholtz, Drew (April 19, 2023). "Blackpink covers iconic TLC and Spice Girls songs in 'Carpool Karaoke'". *Today*. Archived from the original on September 6, 2023. Retrieved September 28, 2023.
193. **^** "How Lady Gaga Influenced Blackpink Into Making Groundbreaking Pop Music". *Music Times*. September 19, 2020. Archived from the original on August 17, 2022. Retrieved May 31, 2022.
194. **^** Benjamin, Jeff (May 31, 2019). "A Timeline of Ariana Grande & Blackpink's Friendship, From Covers to Coachella". *Billboard*. Archived from the original on May 31, 2022. Retrieved May 31, 2022.

</fragment>
<fragment>

On May 18, the group announced a promotional single titled "The Girls" which was released as part of the soundtrack for their mobile game, *Blackpink: The Game* on August 25, 2023.[172][173] It was released alongside a physical version, which debuted at number one on the Circle Album Chart with 160,460 copies sold in the first week, becoming the groups's fifth number-one album.[174] At the 2023 MTV Video Music Awards, Blackpink was awarded Best Choreography for "Pink Venom" as well as Group of the Year, becoming the second girl group ever to win the latter award since TLC in 1999.[175] The Born Pink World Tour concluded on September 17 with two finale concerts in Seoul;[176] by the end of its run, it broke the record held by Spice Girls' Spice World – 2019 Tour to become the highest grossing concert tour of all time by a female group.[177] It drew 1.8 million attendees in total, making it the most-attended concert tour by a Korean girl group.[178][179]


</fragment>
</document>

<fragment>
![](image)The official logo of Blackpink
On June 29, YG Entertainment confirmed that the new girl group would have four members instead of the originally planned nine and revealed its official name as Blackpink.[23] According to a label representative, the group's name meant "pretty isn't everything" and symbolized that "they are a team that encompasses not only beauty, but also great talent".[24] Jisoo later disclosed in a press conference that other group names under consideration included Pink Punk, Baby Monster, and Magnum.[25] Blackpink released their first dance practice video on July 6, which garnered much public attention.[26] On July 29, YG Entertainment confirmed that Blackpink's debut would be on August 8, 2016.[27]



### 2016–2017: Debut, rising popularity, and commercial success[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>

Blackpink have broken numerous records throughout their career; their Born Pink World Tour (2022–23) became the highest grossing concert tour by a female group. They have the most-subscribed and most-viewed music artist channel on YouTube, and are the most-followed and most-streamed girl group on Spotify. Their other accolades include several Guinness World Records, Golden Disc Awards, *Billboard* Music Awards, People’s Choice Awards, and MTV Video Music Awards, among them the first Group of the Year win by a girl group in the 21st century. Blackpink was also the first female Korean group to receive a Brit Award nomination and the first girl group to enter *Forbes*' 30 Under 30 Asia, and was named *Time*'s 2022 Entertainer of the Year. The group has been acknowledged as one of the most powerful celebrities in South Korea by *Forbes* Korea (ranking within the top three in 2019–23), and by former South Korean President Moon Jae-in as a global K-pop phenomenon helping spread K-pop worldwide.




</fragment>

<fragment>
Promotions for the group's debut began in the first week of August 2016 with the release of teaser images, videos, and advertisements.[28][29] The first girl group to debut under YG Entertainment in seven years,[30] Blackpink released their debut single album, *Square One*, on August 8, 2016, consisting of tracks "Boombayah" and "Whistle".[30] They charted at number one and two, respectively, on the *Billboard* World Digital Song Sales chart, making Blackpink the fastest act to achieve such a feat and the third YG Entertainment artist to hold the top two positions simultaneously, after Psy and Big Bang.[31] Upon release, "Whistle" quickly swept all the Korean music charts and debuted at number one on the Gaon Digital Chart.[32][33] Blackpink's first music show performance aired on August 14, 2016, on SBS's *Inkigayo*.[34] They won first place on *Inkigayo* fourteen days after their debut.[35] They wrapped up promotions for *Square One* on September 11, 2016, with another win on *Inkigayo*.[36]

<fragment>

On January 6, 2018, Blackpink released the first episode of their first reality show, *Blackpink House*, which comprised 12 episodes released throughout 2018 following the four members spending 100 days of vacation as they moved into their new dorm, via their official V Live and YouTube channels.[59] On March 28, Blackpink re-released their debut Japanese EP under the name *Re:Blackpink*. The digital version included the same songs as the original release, while the physical version included a DVD of all their music videos and six songs in the Korean language.[60]

</fragment>
<fragment>

On May 18, the group announced a promotional single titled "The Girls" which was released as part of the soundtrack for their mobile game, *Blackpink: The Game* on August 25, 2023.[172][173] It was released alongside a physical version, which debuted at number one on the Circle Album Chart with 160,460 copies sold in the first week, becoming the groups's fifth number-one album.[174] At the 2023 MTV Video Music Awards, Blackpink was awarded Best Choreography for "Pink Venom" as well as Group of the Year, becoming the second girl group ever to win the latter award since TLC in 1999.[175] The Born Pink World Tour concluded on September 17 with two finale concerts in Seoul;[176] by the end of its run, it broke the record held by Spice Girls' Spice World – 2019 Tour to become the highest grossing concert tour of all time by a female group.[177] It drew 1.8 million attendees in total, making it the most-attended concert tour by a Korean girl group.[178][179]
